The first few bites were good, but then I was over it. Too much grease, cheese and unnecessary filling. I honestly think that grilled cheese is best prepared when the ingredients are simple. There's too many other ingredients in the sandwiches and I couldn't appreciate it as much as I wanted to.  The soup was nothing special, but nice to dip the grilled cheese into. Neither friend nor I were able to finish our meals... just too much. I felt sluggish afterwards. No room in my tummy to go across the street to 21st Amendment for a water mellon beer after all.
author: Liv A.

description:
Preface: I'm lactose-intolerant (I know, shocker...I'm Asian).  Hey, there are about 40 Million of us in the US alone! (lactose-intolerants, not Asians)  So its kind of a big deal for me to risk having a lunch of cheesy goodness knowing I have to come back to work for the rest of the day.  

With that said, The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen makes it ALL worth it!  

Aside from the ridiculous line of people...most of whom were there to be a part of the trend rather than because they were true grilled cheese fans (bah!...get out of the way!)...everything about this place makes me happy.  

I ordered the Jalapeno Popper.  Oh my...cheese dripping out the sides of the sandwich (the rustic levain bread is so yummy).  I was kinda sketch about the apricot-jalapeno relish at first but it went so perfectly with the cheese and bacon!  It wasn't too much or over the top.  A perfectly filling lunch.  And the side of fruit made me feel less of a glutton.

Next time, I'm trying the Windy City.

Gotta stock up on some Lactaid.  I'm planning on being a regular here.
author: Susan L.

description:
Yah, I can make the Mousetrap at home with ACME's pain au levain and cheese from my cheese shop but I don't serve it with a teeny OJAI PIXIE!

The only way to get Pixies up here is at Monterey Market or Berkeley Bowl or mail order. 

The Mushroom Gruyere with ham is like a more substantial Sourdough Jack with potato.  

The tomato soup is super healthy with just a touch of creme fraiche on top. There's no cream in the body. I didn't like it.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Nine dollars for a grilled cheese? Child Please!
It did taste pretty good, but really?!?
author: Martin B.

description:
Sitting at a sunny table on a Friday, eating a sandwich; three kinds of cheese ooze over bacon and drip from perfectly toasted bread. Also on the table in front of me is a tangy home made pickle, a bag of fancy chips and a draft beer.  It doesn't get much better than this!  I waited weeks for the line to die down and finally had lunch at the American Grilled Cheese Kitchen.  It was totally worth it!

My husband got the mouse trap with bacon, tomatoes and house bread and butter pickles.  I got the jalapeno popper.  Both sandwiches were absolutely divine!  The service was fantastic as well.

I still continue my love affair with the grilled cheese sandwich at Paragon, (http://www.yelp.com/biz/paragon-restaurant-and-bar-san-francisco#hrid:MgIFMzomPSdRoxSGv95biw) however there's plenty of room in SOMA for more delicious cheese on toast!

Insider tip:  They're adding a new cash register this week so the line will hopefully get better.  This wont change the seating shortage and I only hope the kitchen can keep up with the registers.
author: Amy A.

description:
They have gluten-free bread!!!

I heard on the buzz when this joint opened and I shrugged it off, never imagining that I could partake of the yummy toasted grilled cheese goodness. Gluten-free people can't partake in sandwich shops! But no, it turns out that is not the case at all. 

Overall it's a great spot with yummie sammies. I recommend the blue plate special, in which they give you a mini sammie with tomato soup and an apple. An excellent way to spend your lunch!
author: Nissa A.

description: Oh my cheese! This place serves up some tasty sandwiches. I had the mushroom grilled cheese with a cup of tomato soup. Not only was this place clean and the food tasty, but the staff was so completely amazing. My friend that was with me told me we would make a new tradition of going here everytime we find ourselves in SF... I was quick to agree.
author: Nicky L.

description:
WTF people?  Why are you giving this place bad ratings because of the line!?  Seriously?  If you don't want to wait in a line, THEN DONT WAIT IN A G-D LINE.  It's so simple.  Is it the American Grilled Cheese Kitchen's fault that they got a bunch of awesome press and make delicious kitschy treats (a winning combination for hungry SoMa yopro's)?  NO.  Seriously, if yr gonna bitch about waiting in a line, there's a place 2 blocks away that's the definition of fast -- starts with Mc, ends with Donalds.

Also.  Why are people bitching about there being "too much butter"?   1)  They don't use too much butter, 2)  How is it possible to use too much butter??  Butter makes it better fools.  

Anyhow.  That's enough complaining.  Now to sing the praises of THE BEST GRILLED CHESSE SANDWICH i've ever had.  

I, like all the other SoMa yopros, got totally excited by all the great press this joint received pre-launch, and four coworkers and I headed here as soon as it opened to see what all the fuss was about.

We of course encountered the line (duh), and were totally cool waiting for the 30 or so minutes it took to get in.  The staff were really nice while we waited, offering up samples and giving out free pickles to make the wait go by more quickly.  

The sandwiches all looked amazing but I decided to go with jalapeno popper because what could possibly be better than chevre and bacon?  The answer:  nothing.  Such a great sandwich, the mix of chevre, jack, two thick slices of bacon and their amazing apricot-jalapeno relish was divine!  It could have been slightly spicier, but given how sensitive reviewers of this place have been thus far, spice would probably have upset their delicate sensibilities.  

I also got a side salad and some of their house-made pomegranate spice soda, both of which were delicious.  Honestly, I would wait half an hour just to get the soda again it was so good.  All of my coworkers got different sandwiches and all of us were equally impressed and can't wait to go back.  

Thank you Grilled Cheese Kitchen.  Ignore the haters.  Ya'll are delicious and I can't wait til you start cranking out breakfast and dinner.
author: Tom T.

description: mac and cheese is solid.  Long lines due to the local internet folks.  I could eat here everyday and gain 28 pounds per day.  lol.
author: Mot Y.

description:
I finally got to come here!!!!! I got the red and blue (combo of tomato soup and smaller sandwich). I tried the mushroom gruyere grilled sandwich and dipped it into my savory, flavorful tomato soup. They say smaller sandwich, but it was still 2 pieces and lots of soup. I could eat this everyday I think!!

The blackberry lemonade is super tart, beware.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
No one can ever screw up a grilled cheese sandwich...really.  It's not rocket science. But not everyone can make a grilled cheese extraordinary...this place comes close.

With the line outside of this place on a Saturday afternoon, I was pretty sure this sandwich MUST be something special. Maybe because the grilled cheese is just one of those comforting, make-you-feel-all-snuggly kinds of foods, I was pretty stoked.

The prices for these sandwiches are a little steep (The Mousetrap, which is a combo of three different cheeses, starts at $6.) As other reviewers have mentioned, you'd hope that with such prices, the sandwiches would come with a little side...aside from the one strawberry that came with each one of our sandwiches. The Mushroom Gruyere sandwich I had was pretty tasty, though. It was a little on the over-buttered side for my tastes, but still good over all.  My husband had the Windy City and THAT was wonderful!

If the weather permits it, and the crowd is just too much at the restaurant, have them pack it up to go and enjoy your sandwich at the park around the corner. Great comfort food for a picnic.
author: Heather G.

description: Excellent meal, but I would call the sandwiches more of a panini than a grilled cheese!
author: Mike M.

description: If there is a ever a day that you can manage to eat a 2000 calorie lunch this would be the place.  It's decadent and it's really delicious comfort food.
author: Erika S.

description: I haven't had a (good) grilled cheese sandwich since I found out I had celiac disease and had to go gluten free a couple years ago. That is, until I went here. A fun, happy restaurant that serves my choice of any of their sandwiches on my work block!? = HEAVEN. The bread was so good and looked so NOT gluten free that I was almost worried to eat it. Sure, it would be nice if it cost a little less and, sure, the line can be a drag, but the food is delicious, the staff is super friendly, it's a prime location, and there's just no reason I can justify taking any stars off. I will go here once a week until my pants get too tight from my butter and cheese overdose. Then maybe just once every other week ;o)
author: Katherine R.

description:
If you're going to really enjoy this place you have to know when to go! It's all about breakfast during the week and lunch on weekends! The wait can get pretty long otherwise. 

It's all about grilled cheese here (obviously)! Every one of there sandwiches are amazing! The tomato soup is the perfect accessory to any of their sandwiches. DIP IT! Their raspberry lemonade is super tasty and delish, but I always go for the $3 mimosa on the weekends! Speaking of the weekends, all of the breakfast grilled cheese sandwiches come with an egg making it the most hearty and tasty breakfast around. I'm drooling!
author: Casi C.

description:
Overpriced, tiny sandwiches on bread that grills up too crunchy to qualify as a real grilled cheese sandwich. 

I'm a big fan of grilled cheese and expected to dig the hell out of this place, but it ends up being nothing more than a place to milk money out of overpaid dotcommers. 

:(
author: Dan S.

description:
Stopped in here for a quick bite before heading to a Giants game.  I was super pleased with the menu items - I'm a huge fan of grilled cheese, and I love that they incorporate so many different and unique types of cheeses into their sammies.  I ordered the mushroom gruyere - it blew my socks off.  They also have some fun beverage selections, including local beers and homemade lemonades and teas.  The restaurant itself was packed, but it was fine for us because we took our sandwiches to go.  All in all, four sandwiches and four drinks (two of which were beers) with a tip, we were out the door for $55 - not bad!  

My only complaint - we had to wait a REALLY long time for our food to be ready.  Like close to 25 minutes.  I understand they were busy, but they are making sandwiches...I felt like people who ordered their food to eat in the restaurant were serviced in a more timely manner than my to-go order.  All in all, great food at a reasonable price, conveniently located near AT&T Park - I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Jenna C.

description:
For me, this place is not worth the price.
1. There's always a long line for lunch.
2. Portions are small.
3. It is pricey for what it is.
4. The bread is crusty and hard to bite.

I'm glad I tried it once. But I doubt I will go back. I can make a much better grilled cheese sandwich at home.
author: Ayse C.

description: The Mousetrap with a side of bacon, plus regular coffee = $10.21?  I know they tell us the recession is over - apparently these guys really believe it.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This may come as no surprise given the name, but if you want a grilled cheese sandwich, this is THE place to go. 

I got the tomato and feta with olive tapenade and it was perfection. The flavors and textures seemed so well thought out - add a vanilla ginger mint housemade soda to the mix and you've got lunchtime heaven. Next time I'm going all out and trying the Reubenesque.

Rumor Mill: I heard the owners met in the elevator after both getting laid off at Oracle. Is that true? Talk about fate! I heard the woman who put the menu together has won the Grilled Cheese Invitational. I also heard one of the owners is responsible for the Stunner of the Month club. Très hip, huh?

PS: Milk and cookie happy hour = brilliant!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I wanted to love this place, I did. BUT...

Had the 8 dollar special that consisted of a grilled cheese of my choice and a salad or soup. Got the havarti and mushroom sandwich and a salad. I can deal with the fact that the salad was just plain greens (not even of good quality) very small and had absolutely nothing special about it whatsoever, the dressing wasn't even good.

What I can't deal with: The sandwich was SOOOO tiny, half the size of my companions (she didn't like her food either) BUT not only was it tiny, not only did they give me heels of the bread (both sides, and I like heels) BUT the cheese wasn't melted and there was so little of it, I seriously had to open it up and examine it to make sure there was cheese in it. The mushrooms were so strong tasting I suspect there was truffle oil used in addition to them. Why nor just use good quality mushrooms!?

No reason to go back, saw nothing redeeming about the place. I mean if you are a grilled cheese restaurant, grill your cheese!
author: Kara S.

description:
The perfect way to cure a hangover. I didn't even realize they had breakfast sandwich grilled cheeses until the other day - this rocked my world. And, these are less expensive than the regular ones...score! We had the Classic Breakfast and the Jalepeno Popper w/egg - I know, don't be jealous.

Their lunch sammys are delish too, I really can't say enough good things about a place that serves oozy gooey melted cheese sandwiches with fixins like applewood-smoked bacon, roasted wild mushrooms, etc. As another poster mentioned the sandwiches are a little on the greasy side - but isn't this the point? I want my grilled cheese sandwiches to be decadent and AGCK's totally are.

The only downside is that service is a wee bit slow.
author: Britt M.

description:
I do like the concept.  I've had the Jalapeno popper, Piglet, and Mousetrap  (with bacon) and they're all yummy.  They were evenly toasted and had the right critically important ratio of crunchiness to meltiness.

I like the price for what they offer.  These sandwiches are not made with Kraft singles; they use quality cheese and bread.

I like that they offer a small side salad ($3 - with actual dark greens!) so that I don't totally hate myself after I eat one of the sandwiches.

The problem I have is they are SLOW.  It's nice for a casual weekend brunch, sure, but on a weekday at 1 pm I waited 19 minutes for a sandwich.  (Yes, I timed it.  I'm cranky when I'm hungry.)    

I think the problem stems from the batch-wise process.  They can only make so many sandwiches in one batch, so when it's busy you are guaranteed to wait through 2-3 batches.

The process engineer in me wants to help, but the cranky consumer in me will probably not go back - at least not when I want a fast lunch.
author: James S.

description:
Went back to The American today. It was actually my third visit - last week I popped in when they stayed open a little later to get one of their grapefruit-pink peppercorn sodas but didn't grab any food - and I was much happier this time.

I ordered the Jalapeño Popper, since I'd seen some back-and-forth on Facebook about some tweaks to its apricot-jalapeño spread, on regular bread this time (doctor's orders to stay on gluten til proven that I can't have it). I also picked up one of the Empire sodas from the case (next time is an Abita root beer, I looove Abita) and a ginger molasses cookie.

I don't know what the spread on the Popper used to be, but I loved it. It was one of those "omg this is so spicy, hurts so good" sort of moments. The sandwich seemed a lot bigger and everything was crispy and delicious. I was muuuuch happier this time.

As far as the fruit inclusion - the apricot was pretty yummy. The tangerines last time were good too of course but somehow the apricot worked better (or maybe it was just because I had the Popper).

I also want to note that every single time I've been here -- even when I was just getting a soda -- everyone working has seemed to be in great spirits, willing to chat a little and just really lively and happy. 

I still wish the price were a little lower, though! I guess this will just have to be a once-every-couple-weeks type lunch (I shoot for less than $10 for lunch; today my American lunch came out to $14 even).

Keep an eye on this place -- they're listening to our feedback and getting better!
author: Jess H.

description:
Ooooo, melty cheese and butter that clings to your fingers. Ooey gooey awesomeness. There's napkins, but why ruin a perfectly good opportunity to lick all that delicious flavor off your fingers?!? The bacon in the Jalapeno Popper sammich and the smoky tomato soup are so darned good together, it oughta be a crime.

Oh my god, the blondie. I'd like an entire house made out of these blondies so I could eat my way out! And by the way, the swimming pool would be filled with the yummy house sodas (spicy pomegrate? hells ya!!)

If you want one of the awesome sunny outdoor tables, you better get there early, because the word is out, my friend. And trust me, you want one.

The only thing I can possibly hate about this place is that they've converted me into a SuperFan. I just thought I was getting lunch... Who knew I'd need a big foam finger and a cheerleading outfit?
author: Andrea T.

description:
Waited 1:10 for a sandwich.  Yes, 1 hour, 10 minutes.  I saw 1 guy in the kitchen.  

Got the Jalapeno Popper which is not spicy at all.  Is it good?  Yeah, it's tasty but not worth $9.50 - given all the other options around SOMA.  I also had their butterscotch and pecan blondie as well, which I'd come back for again on it's own.

I'll be back in a couple of months after the crowd subsides and see how it is then.
author: Matt D.

description:
The situation: This place has gotten a lot of hype, particularly for being Yelped about in such a maniacal fashion after opening a couple weeks ago. (wooo meta!)

My perspective: I'm strategically set up across the street (my office window actually overlooks American Grilled Cheese Kitchen), so I can tell you what's up with the place now that it's been a week or two.

What's up with the place:
1. The wait - chill out friends! it's already dying down significantly, so this highly publicized pain point soon become moot. Also, having worked in SOMA for some years now, HELL YES we will line up outside a new lunch establishment.  We've already exhausted the other lunch options in this hood so spectacularly that trying out a frozen mini bagel buffet in the company conference room could probably entice. There's something new, hence we're psyched. But it'll regulate itself soon. 

2. The sammys - what they say is true, I'm afraid. Portions are just this side of wanting, with a little too much butter (drip drip) and just barely enough of the bread and cheese. That said, it's still pretty damned delicious, and you can bet that on a rainy day I will happily head across the street for their comfort food delights, $8 bucks or otherwise. 

3. The other eats - I tried out my friend's bread pudding, and it was SUPER yummy. If i wasnt such a purist (hello its the grilled cheese kitchen) i woulda ordered it myself. Maybe next time. Also chocolate chip cookies are decent and the butterscotch brownie freakin ROCKS. I wasnt even interested til the free sample, then suddenly i'm stalking the free sample guy. That's what you get for giving out dessert morsels senor! 

4. The service - kitchen's still working out the kinks, and the counter staff/free sample guy are kind of high gear hospitality robots (this always kinda freaks me out but it beats the nonchalant hipster alternative), but over all the vibe is cheerful and accommodating. And again, who doesnt love free samples when you're already eating? That's just pure and simple generosity in my book. 

A little bigger on the portions, a little mellower with the grease factor and these guys'll be in great shape soon enough.
author: Jacqueline V.

description:
The grilled cheese sandwiches were, for the most part, pretty solid!   I order the Mushroom Gruyere with tomato soup.  I loved the chopped up mushrooms in the mild gruyere cheese.  But, the best part is the potato....these were little pleasant surprises!   As for the tomato soup, it complimented the grilled cheese, but it wasn't anything to rave about -- I've definitely had better elsewhere.  

My husband, on the other hand, went the classic route and order the Mousetrap sandwich with tomato soup.  He didn't dislike it, but he didn't seem too impressed.  He tried a bite of my sandwich and liked mine much better.

Now, based on reading other people's reviews and hearing my husband's comment, the consensus seems to be to get the grilled cheese with some kind of meat, mushroom, or potato.  The classic sandwich is fine, but the other variations are better.  Not to mention, the next time I'm here, I'm going to try to lobster mac n cheese.  We saw some people eating it and It looked amazing!  I'll be back....
author: Jen P.

description: I was excited to hear about this place because they offer gluten-free sandwiches.  I had a sandwich and salad combo and neither were very good.  The salad was pretty bland and didn't have much dressing.  The sandwich was OK, but didn't have much cheese or flavor.  Not what I was expecting from a place famous for grilled cheese.  It wasn't cheap either.  The nice part is that they have a very nice outdoor patio where you can eat with your dog.
author: Scott L.

description:
I sense a great danger.  The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen is:

a) packed with expertly made grilled cheese goodness
b) staffed with super-friendly, hard working folks
c) close to home
d) across the street from 21st Amendment
e) blessed with a *spacious* sidewalk patio
f) dog friendly in their patio

No, it's not a multiple choice question.  It is a litany of seduction.   Taste the grilled cheese at your peril.  You may never return.

Seriously.  This new little sandwich shop has a ton of great things going for it.  And the greatest of those things is, dare I say it, NOT the grilled cheese.  Certainly the food is tasty, but the differentiator for AGCK is that it feels like a well-run business already.  All of the staff I interacted with were warm, friendly, and actually thinking about how to  do the best for their customers.

Granted, I showed up just as all of the food was running out, so I didn't have to wait in line for 45 minutes.  But given the crowds over the past few days, and the fact that everyone working here had to put up with those crowds, the positive attitude is even more impressive.

Now onto the food.  AGCK preps all of their sandwich materials the day before, so they will actually sell out of menu items.  This was the case when I arrived 20 minutes before closing.   Two sandwiches were available:  Feta Tomato, and Reuben.  I wanted soup, so I opted for the Feta Tomato.  As others have noted, there's a hefty spread of tapenade on this sandwich.  Good thing I like olives :-)  The soup came with homemade croutons, and tasted exactly like tomato soup should -- just a little creamy, just a little sour, and all tomato.

My restaurant gold standard for tomato soup and grilled cheese is the Tomato Bisque at Sauce, which comes with truffled grilled cheese.  That dish is still tops for dinner, but Sauce's bisque is way too heavy for lunch and I can never manage to eat there without having a few beers.  Enter AGCK for an ideal soup & sandwich lunch combo.
author: Jay M.

description:
What a great idea! Those of you who think a grilled cheese sandwich is just American cheese melted between two slices of Wonder bread are in for a big surprise. The American Grill servers their sandwiches with a variety of breads, cheeses, and other fillings. Aside from their sandwiches, they also make homemade sodas and teas, and they make a conservative effort to be Green. 

Try it! You'll be pleasantly surprised.
author: Stephan H.

description:
Crowd is now typical SOMA South Beach eclectic...

Sandwiches are still amazing crispy outside gooey inside.  Cheddar, jack, havarti + roasted tomatoes = heavenly.

Worth the wait, but I'd just get there early and not worry about it.  Good beer & wine too!
author: Melanie C.

description:
Greasy, overpriced, and small portions; unless you order the Mousetrap, which only has cheese in it, all the other options are like a regular sandwich, but smaller. You'll be wondering where the grilled cheese is exactly.

I had the Turkey Havarti, BF had the Piglet and tomato soup and a lemonade; total of $26, $28 w/ tip. Their cupcakes, $3.50?! So glad I didn't get one, I KNOW i would've been disappointed. 

The male friends we ran into all got two sandwiches because of how small they were.

One of their GFs got a Jalapeno Popper sandwich; she was expecting it to be spicy, it was sweet. 

This place is unbelievably overhyped. It shouldn't be so hard to make a good grilled cheese sandwich. It's so simple. Their mistake is that they've overcomplicated the selections. 

For tomato soup go to Axis Cafe in Potrero Hill. If you're into grilled cheese, try my favorite for a dollar more at Bix Restaurant. They're Truffle Cheese and Sweet Onion Croques (grilled sandwich) are 10x better. They use truffle cheese for gods sake...there was no mention of truffle cheese at this place. Lame.
author: Maria A.

description:
Cheesy. MMM. 
Bacon. MMM. 
Bread. MMM. 
Tomato Soup. Double MMM. 

Not obvs enough? I like this place! I mean, it's the classic combination of grilled cheese and tomato soup touched up just enough to make it gourmet without being pretentious - how can that go wrong? 

I ordered the Jalapeno Popper, but subbed the chevre for good old Tilamook sharp cheddar and added a cup of tomato soup. It was a lot of food, but boy was it tasty! My sandwich was savory with a slight hint of sweet via the relish, and it also had the perfect crunch. The tomato soup wasn't the best I've ever had, but it was definitely a nice complement to the sandwich, and I would readily order it again because it makes the sandwich that much better.   

Contrary to some reviews, I think service is ok. We found open seats quickly. And parking was breeze.  Price wise, I think it was a bit steep (over $25.00 for two people, for lunch. EEK.)
author: Jessica R.

description: Great food and reasonably priced. The Piglet and Mousetrap are my favorites. The Blue Plate Special, which is basically a half sandwich plus soup or salad, is a great lunch value. Their house-made seasonal lemonades kick it from 4 stars to 5 stars.
author: Ian S.

description:
I went today for lunch. Got there as soon as it opened and managed to get in and out with literally zero line and zero wait. I contemplated saving my sandwich for later (it is only 11, after all) but it smelled so good I figured I would regret not eating it hot off the press.

I got the Piglet. It was amazing. The only thing I would change is the apple mustard. It adds A LOT of flavor, but I honestly feel like it adds a little TOO much. I think it's a great flavor enhancer, but that it should be used VERY sparingly. Part of the appeal of a grilled cheese is the simplicity. 

That said, it was a delicious, crusty, buttery, cheesy delight and I cannot wait to come back and try some of the others.

It is important to note that I have officially placed AGCK ahead of Paragon on my list of "world's best grilled cheese sandwiches" (currently the only two contenders), mainly because the bread is more manageable and doesn't destroy the roof of my mouth.

Well done American Grilled Cheese Kitchen!
author: Carrie W.

description:
Move over Ike's, San Francisco has a new sandwich king!

The sandwiches had great complimenting flavors, and the passionfruit lemonade was amazing. The homemade soda and pickles were also quite pleasing. 

What We Ordered

Mushroom Gruyere 
Feta Tomato
Deli-style pickle
Passionfruit lemonade
House made soda

All for less then $26 and a great experience for 2

Tips:
Get there early,
Sit at the counter and watch the food come out and talk with the friendly staff

Finally, the reason it's better then Ike's;
The interior makes it possible to actually talk with the staff (who listen to feed back; the manager asked our opinion of the amount of olive in one of the sandwiches because of yelp reviews). Also the sandwiches come with a clementine which is awesome. I love Ike's but they need a new place and until then this will be my sandwich shop.

Finally, If you are one of the people complaining about the long line, get there earlier or wait for the 'new restaurant' hype to die down a bit. We got over there around 10:50am, waited 10minutes for them to open. Ordered and received our food by 11:20 and we were about 6th in line with a huge take out order before us.
author: Katie P.

description:
Your expectations continue to grow each minute that you have to wait for your food.  I've read that there's some peeps who had to wait close to an hour just to get a grilled cheese sandwich. Doesn't that sound ridiculous? Repeat: "I waited 1 hour for a grilled cheese sandwich" (On a side note, I waited almost 2 hours for a stinking hot dog at Pink's in LA).

But thankfully each minute you're left to wait is not unnoticed here. They were giving out pickles (the house made pickle was delicious!!!) and dessert samples to all the patrons in line.  And it was definitely a long line. I hoped to beat the lunchtime rush by coming at 11:30 AM, but a lot of peeps must've been thinking the same thing, because the place was packed. But at least I didn't wait an hour, I think the time it took for me to wait in line and receive my food was around 20-25 mins.

I ordered the Jalapeno Popper, and it was tasty. Definitely not like any other grilled cheese I've had before. It was not as spicy as I hoped, but  it was zesty, tangy, and the bread was nice and crunchy. It was definitely tasty and a good enough size to get me full. My order came with a tangerine, which was a perfect way to end the meal. 

I'll be back again. (But at $9 for my sandwich, I might not be back as soon as I would like)
author: Jeffrey J.

description:
A few friends mentioned this restaurant to me when hearing of my favourite cookbook "Great Grilled Cheese".  I used to work in this area but sadly our office moved before this cute little shop opened up.  I made a point of going over to it to have lunch while out biking in the SOMA area.

First off, this place is small and therefore it will fill up fast. I went in at 11:58 am on a Saturday and it was busy but I was served quickly... and then 15 people came in behind me!  I think they've got a good reputation going around so a lot of people head over around lunch.  The tables inside and out were full, which I didn't mind since I planned on going over to the park anyway.

To my dismay, the menu only has 5 or 6 sandwiches on it, if that.  There wasn't even half the variety I would have expected from a restaurant advertising itself as specializing in grilled cheese.  In comparison, my tiny little cookbook has at least 30 GC recipes in it.  I really hope they'll look to expand their menu here.  To their benefit though, the sandwiches they do have listed look amazing.

I ordered the Mushroom Gruyere sandwich, figuring I'd take a chance on mushrooms and potatoes (seriously, there's potatoes in this sandwich!!)  Second drawback to this place: I know they were busy, but wow, what a long wait time to get my food!  Eventually they did get it out to me and I headed over to South Park with it to relax, soak in the sun, and enjoy my sandwich.

And damn, enjoy I did!  The mix of potatoes and minced mushroom blended so well together, I was floored by it.  To be honest, I'd actually forgotten there was potato in the sandwich until I took a bite and had a pleasant surprise by the flavour and texture.  My takeout container also came with a very juicy apple, a great side to my sandwich.

I've read a few reviews that say the sandwiches are small and over-priced.  Honestly, I couldn't finish mine.  I could see it being not enough for someone with a hearty appetite, but I had more than my fill out of it and I'd been biking around SOMA for a few hours (so I was pretty hungry by the time I got lunch).  Price-wise, it's on par for the area.  I paid $12 for my sandwich and drink, which is what I'd expect for most of the lunch meals in the SOMA area.

I would definitely go back and would love to try the soup and some of the other sandwiches.  I think they would benefit from increasing their menu, speeding up their serve time and getting more seating space, but the food is worth checking this place out, at least once.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
I braved Giants fans to get that grilled cheese and I still give it 4 stars!

This is one of those new types of small restaurants that are based around food you typically eat at home (or in a ballpark). Like how a few years ago hot dog restaurants  got all popular. This is the grilled cheese version. MMMM grilled cheese....

It is my personal opinion that nothing tastes better in this world than a nice piece of good quality toasted bread with good butter on it. That exact combo is the building block of a grilled cheese! 

What says grilled cheese more than hoards of Giants fans fresh off their high of watching the World Series winners roll down Market St. in their cable cars? Just ask the fans standing on second Street with open bottles of champagne, what would you like for lunch? I bet they all say 'Grilled Cheese!!' because they were all eating here!

Ok ok I just wanted an excuse to write about all the Giants fans swarming the streets near my place of employment.

Back to the food. it really was tasty. I agree with some of the other posters, a little on the small side. Not much meat. but enough. One of the problems in this country is redonkulous portion sizes. You won't find that here. But you will find that the portion is enough. It's perfect sized. Yes, it's a little expensive but you're eating 2 blocks away from Giants stadium in the financial/South of Market area.... nothing here is inexpensive except for lees deli and that mexican place over on 4th. Prices here are on par with everyplace else in this neighborhood.

BTW for .50c extra you can get your grilled cheese on home made gluten free bread! That's a real plus for those with gluten allergies as it's really challenging to find gluten free options usually.

Things I liked about this place:

Grilled cheeses - several variety/combo of sandwiches. I had the Don something with Sopressata salami and pesto. Excellent!
The cute little apple that comes as a side
The home-made 'sodas' today I had a blueberry lemon soda - also excellent!
Nice feel
Good 'green' practices
Donates all uneaten apples that come with every lunch to a local food kitchen
GLUTEN FREE BREAD!!!


Minus one star because when I bit into the apple there was a nasty old bruise in it. It grossed me out. Ok, I'm picky about fruit, you probably wouldn't mind it.
author: Kelly C.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here today to try this place after walking by here and it always being closed. Because they are only open for lunch normally, 11-3 on weekdays, it is hard to get here without making plans ahead of time. But, today, they started being opening on Saturdays and they were open from 12-4. We got there just after 12 and the line was already 15 people deep.

We were not surprised by the line and it was not a big deal because we expected it. We ordered a Wild Turkey and a Windy City for the two of us. They were awesome. As far as taste, they really have nailed it. They have a good thing going here and it doesn't seem like they are one of those companies that opens and closes within the same month. 

I would give them a full 5 stars for taste alone, but there are a couple things I was a little surprised about that make me take one star away. I was a little surprised at the prices. I understand; they are in SOMA where their lease is expensive so they at least have to cover that. But, consider what you are selling, a grilled cheese and grapes. That should never cost $9, no matter where your restaurant is. I was also kind of surprised that everything was pre-made and then baked to make sure the cheese melted and bread toasted. 

I am glad we came here once. The owners are cool and like to talk to their customers. I would probably come again, but probably not until I have another craving for a grilled cheese.
author: Michael C.

description:
Was in from out of town, and intentionally went here last week, as I heard about it via the twitter/facebook world.

I decided to try two sandwiches (I intentionally skipped breakfast), and wanted to start with their basic grilled cheese, the Mousetrap.

The Mousetrap was your basic grilled cheese, but made with really awesome cheese. It was cooked just right, and the cheese was hot, but not burn your tongue hot. I was happy.

Then I tried the Mushroom Gruyère, as it sounded awesome. Fontina, gruyère, roasted wild mushrooms + gold potatoes, melted leeks, thyme butter: How could it get any better? Well, it was awesome. The blend of the gruyère cheese with the mushrooms were so good, and the potatoes, sliced thinly and with the cheese melted around it was very tasty.

Also the homemade soda was awesome, made right in front of you at the counter.

Definitely gonna go back when I'm next in town.
author: Mark M.

description:
Heard about this place 6 months prior to opening... So excited... Can't wait... Are you open yet? When do you open? I want my two pieces of toast with melted cheese! 

On a whim one day last week, I did a search and discovered it was opening THAT DAY.  Ran out of my office and got in line around 11:30.  Doors not open yet.  OK, I have waited six months, I was willing to wait another 45 mins - an hour.  Wait ended up being hour and a half.  OK, its opening day, they are working out the kinks...   

"At least my grilled cheese is going to be the best I have ever had...!"

The Jalepeno Popper by description alone was my driving motivation to wait in that monstrosity of a grand opening line.  The ingredients were sure to produce a party in my mouth - and my taste buds had their dancing shoes on! 

Needless to say, all the hype works against their favor.  The place is cute, the employees are nice, and I'm sure they are working on a quicker turnaround.  But what it comes down to is the taste.  The juice here is not worth the squeeze.  It was kinda tasty, but just lackluster, not as wonderful as the description makes you think it will be, and def not worth $10 to still be hungry at the end of it all.  

Maybe not everyone can make a better one at home, but I am pretty sure I can.
author: Dulce V.

description:
Was that a slice of heaven i just ate??? why yes it was! The Jalapeno Popper might be the best sandwich I have ever had the pleasure of eating! The apricot/jalapeno relish was the perfect balance of sweet and hot. The cheese...don't even get me started!

For a place that just opened this week, with a lot of fanfare...they handled the crowd better than any restaurant I have seen in recent past. The passed out samples as the line grew longer. 

This place ROCKS!!! I will be back 4 Sure!
author: Wendy W.

description:
I like this place because I like grilled cheese sandwiches a lot. A LOT.  

The mushroom gruyere is delicious, but in general, I don't find the menu to be all that inventive. If I'm going to spend $8+ on bread + cheese + some other ingredients, it should be better and more creative than something I can make in 5 minutes at home.  

Also they don't serve fries, which is 90% of the reason I ever go out for grilled cheese.

That said, if you do not know how to heat bread on butter on a pan and throw some cheese on it (I understand how difficult this can be) and maybe throw some garlic and onions into the mix (but be careful, this involves a knife and you could hurt yourself!) then you should definitely come here to enjoy the wonder that is a grilled cheese sandwich.
author: Richa A.

description:
This place didn't live up to its name, I expected a restaurant/café version of the Grilled Cheese Truck (http://www.thegrilledcheesetruck.com/), but it was just another sandwich and salad place.  I had the Moscone (fresh mozzarella, fontina, roasted tomatoes, basil-lavender pesto, kalamata olive tapenade) for $8 and Ginger lemonade.  

The sandwich filling was delicious, and the perfect amount.  Not too cheesy.  I just wish they didn't over toast their breads.  Maybe I'll make a request, if I go there again.  

The ginger lemonade was disgusting.  I added sugar, honey, sweet nectar (that's what they called it), but nothing helped it.  It was overly concentrated.  I finally put half of it in another cup with water and a lot of ice, and then it was drinkable.  

It wasn't too crowded, but they had a hard time keeping up with the orders.  We had to wait for almost 30 mins to get our sandwiches, that's a big disappointment considering its a lunch place.  Sorry, I don't want to spend 50% of my lunch time waiting for food.  

Not sure if I'll walk all the way here again.
author: Anoo L.

description:
I waited a few weeks for the hoopla to die down before trying this place. I just cant handle lines like they were getting at lunchtime. Went with a co-worker right when they opened at 11am. The staff was very friendly and the place is really cute. 

The actual sandwich was just OK (the bread was a little too hard for my liking, but that could be becase I have braces!).  But the tomato soup was really good.  I will definitely go back since they are so close to my office and I think the price for the Mousetrap and tomato soup is pretty reasonable ($8).
author: Kara F.

description:
Grilled Cheese is an all time American classic. Two slices of bread and a slice of cheese in the middle.  Grill it. and Voila! Melted, toasty goodness.  Now, let me tell you, this place just brought the classic up a notch.  

I've ordered the Jalepeno Popper - jalepeno jelly and goat cheese = yummy in my book.  

I also love their tomato soup - pretty good!  It's a little spicy, but not TOO spicy.  

It's a little pricey for what it is, but I would still come here again to order the soup and jalepeno popper again anytime ;)
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
The grilled cheese sandwich in its modern form probably came to us in the 60s according to the Food Timeline, with several variations preceeding.  So it'd be hard to find someone who doesn't have fond memories of grilled cheese sandwiches as a kid, and in SOMA, near South Park in the heart of the land of hipsters and technies, everyone has a visceral reaction to the thought of an eatery specializing in grilled cheese sandwiches.

The place was co-founded by Heidi Gibson, who is not only a former software developer, but a seven-time winner of the Grilled Cheese Invitational in LA. With that background, opening up a place like this makes perfect sense.

So, everyone knows about the hype. Everyone knows about the long-ass line. So, does the food live up?

I got the Jalapeño Popper. Just what one would expect. Spicy peppers, but not very hot, with creamy chevre, and some monterey jack and bacon (apple-smoked) to give it some structure. Delicious combo. All the sandwiches use country-style levain bread (there is a gluten-free option) grilled to buttery crunchiness. It was good enough to make me feel it'd be worth coming back to try the others.  One observation on the menu is that I would like to have seen a classic sandwich on wonder bread and american cheese. One should always pay tribute to one's roots. The sandwich also comes with some fresh red grapes. (If they put it in a paper sack with a carton of milk and ritz crackers and cheese handi-snack and you'd have something.)

The restaurant is small, about 20 can fit inside, 30 outside. Excellent selection of craft sodas (try one of the two sodas for the day!), and there's an assortment of non-sandwiches, such as chips, soups, salad, etc. Service was exceptionally friendly. And for further goodness, almost everything is compostable/recyclable/reusable.

Some suggestions. Come Early!! I got there at 11:20, and the wait was tolerable. If you come during the lunch rush, you are screwed. On a nice day, take it to go, and eat in South Park around the corner. On a less than nice day, if you can find a seat inside, it's a good place for people watching.
author: Boris C.

description: This place is awesome! They stayed open late for the giants game and it was a great pre-game meal. I got the jalapeno popper wiht mushrooms instead of bacon and it was super tasty. The apricot jelly seemed sort of random, but actually tasted amazing. My friends were very happy with their sandwiches too. Will definitely come back. Wish they had more beers on tap though!
author: Vinitha R.

description:
I was craving grilled cheese and was about to eat at Cowgirl Creamery in the Ferry Plaza Building when I heard about The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen. One look at the menu and I knew I had to eat here.

The Mushroom Gruyere and Jalepeno Popper (without bacon) are both delish. Don't bother getting soup because it tastes kind of like jarred pasta sauce. The side salad isn't very exciting either. Basically don't even try to come here and be healthy and balance out your greasy grilled cheese because the sides really don't measure up. Plus, your grilled cheese will be more than filling though.

After you eat here, you'll either want to pass out for a couple hours or run a couple miles. Either way, you'll be very happy.
author: Shreya O.

description:
What a treat!  I heard the owners on Martha Stewart Radio on XM when planning a trip to San Fran.  And had to try it.  They did not dissapoint.  
I will say my hubby had the basic grilled cheese. And while quality, I would suggest you try something unique...because thats where the money is!  WOW!  I'm not generally a goat cheese fan, but I find that it mellows out when heated so I took the plunge and tried the Jalapeno Popper!  WOW!!!!!!!!  It was a flavor explosion and the best sandwich I have ever had.  The goat cheese was creamy, the bacon was crisped to perfection, the jalapeno Popped with heat and the apricot cooled it all down.  Amazing! I had the red white and blue plate special so the sandwich was on the smaller side, but still a great portion especially when paired with the fabulous smokey tomato soup.  Ooooh!  I wish  they had a location in So Cal! I'm craving it now.  The creme and croutons on top took it over the edge!  I would highly recommend this place!
author: Karen T.

description:
Stopped in here on a sunny Saturday afternoon to get some lunch with my girlfriend. Not having been here wasn't sure what was good and what wasn't.

My gf ordered the Red White and Blue special I think it was called basically a smaller sandiwch and choice of coup or salad. She opted for the tomato soup.

We both ordered the Mouse trap which had a few kinds of cheese and a tangy mustard. The sandwich was really good with one exception and a pet peeve of mine of places that specialize in grilled cheese sandwiches. Too much butter on the grilled bread. Might just be my preference but I find a lot of places just put too much butter making the grilled cheese sandwich too greasy. Other than the cheeses combined with the mustard were tasty.

My full size sandwich I thought was pretty big and in the future I would order the soup/salad sandwich combo. The sandwich in that deal is only slightly smaller than the full size so for 8/9 bucks you get what looked like a full bowl of soup.

The tomato soup is pretty delicious also by the way. They also had a really tasty berry flavored lemonade that was used to make an Arnold Palmer. They even offered a side of iced tea since the lemonade is made with real lemons and can be a bit more tart.  Place is good at what it does and the food is quality.
author: Hyung L.

description: Omg the jalapeno popper... *drools* the perfect combination of sweet and spicy. This grilled cheese is highly recommended and I'm not even a huge grilled cheese person!
author: Jamie T.

description:
I've tried the Mousetrap, Mushroom Gruyere, Jalapeno Popper, Smoky Tomato Soup, the blondie, the cookie, the passionfruit lemonade, and the house made sodas.  No complaints, all the way around.

This place is a great stop for lunch, for a quick snack, or for any reason really. If you're in SoMa, you can't go wrong at The American SF. The staff is fast, polite, and helpful.  The atmosphere is all-American and fun. And the sandwiches are one scrumptious bite after another.  I can't wait for them to launch a delivery service. 5 star.
author: Ian F.

description: Greasy grilled cheese sandwiches. YUM! I've tried the mousetrap with bacon and mushroom gruyere, both were delicious, about $10 a sandwich, not cheap but it hits the spot. I also got the their tomato soup which I thought was pretty bland.This place gets packed, so go after the lunch rush, not many seats, it's a take-out type of place.
author: Ennie L.

description:
Best grilled cheese sandwich ever. Sorry mom.

Take that as you wish of course. I don't have much cheese credibility. If you've read my yelps, you know I usually praise places that leave it off when I ask. But not here.

The turkey club, an unbelievable combination of Tillamook cheddar, smoked turkey, mustard, tomatoes and arugula on country wheat, momentarily converted me to the biggest cheese fan ever. And that was without the havarti and bacon which I had left off. Can you imagine?

As part of the Red, White and Blue Plate Special you also get a soup or salad on the side. Outstanding deal for $8.

And let's not forget house baked cookies. Because if you're going for grilled cheese, you better go all in.

From my first trip months ago: House granola for breakfast was just OK. Which basically means come for their namesake. You won't regret it, even if you have to tell Mom she's no longer #1.

Wait was about 20min. I'd wait two hours for something this good.
author: Jason B.

description:
Yes, please. And THANK YOU for coming to the neighborhood.

This place is fun and casual, and so happens to serve up a mean grilled cheese sandwich. Which I suppose is a requisite for naming your restaurant "The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen".

Anyhow, I like soup-sandwich combo. Toggling between the mushroom gruyère sandwich and tomato soup is like an elevated step back into comfort-food land.  And the pickles are awesome, too.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
It's a concept restaurant, and I gotta applaud them for going narrow and deep. I approve of all cheese endeavors. 

The sandwiches are good. A bit too greasy, but only just enough to remind you that you're eating something whose main ingredient is fat, fat, fat. It's quality fat, so it's okay. 

The homemade lemonade and sodas are gourmet beverage necessities. And I figured, since I was already ruining my diet, why not go all the way and also get the butterscotch blondie - YUM! 

The couple who runs it are both friendly and cute. The guy is in a cool band called Sex With No Hands! 

And it's right across from Jeremy's so you can go couture when you're done going gourmet. 

Get there by 11:30 or you'll be doomed to stand in line forevah.
author: Melinda K.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place - I mean a place dedicated to melty oozy cheese? That is heaven. Unfortunately this place is more like purgatory.  Not quite hell but certainly not the heaven it could be.

First the waits are ridiculous - an hour to order and then another 25 minutes for the order. 

When the sandwiches finally arrived, one side was over-toasted and the other totally under toasted. One would think that a place the specialized in grilled cheese sammies would have mastered the toasting part by now.

That said - the place is still finding its "legs" and I think once they figure out the kinks, it could be fabulous. Clearly, they have found a sweet spot in people's tummies by specializing in grilled cheese. Just one look at the line will tell you that.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Cool place.  Feels industrial.  Great for a casual weekend brunch!

The "Piglet" - five stars
The bread is crispy and crunchy, and the sandwich has the right proportion between bread and ingredients.  
Flavor: Great balance of flavor between the saltiness of the ham, the nuttiness of the sharp cheddar and the aroma of the rosemary butter.  Fantastic creation!  Well done.

Mushroom Gruyere - three stars
This one just lacks flavor.  Mushrooms were bland.  They're just sleeping between two pieces of bread.  Come on guys, wake'em up with some herbs, spices or another ingredient.  Or use a mix of more flavorful mushrooms!  The gruyere is tasty but not pretty dull just by itself.

Tangerines with the meal was a nice touch.  Cuts through the grease so you feel less gross after all that cheesy goodness.

I'd come back to try other menu items.
author: Thomas L.

description:
A bunch of us from work were so excited to have a new food option in the neighborhood, so we headed on over to try it out at 11am today. Turns out they open at 11:30, PLUS a few other people had the same idea we did, so our wait time ended up being an hour and a half before we were eating our sandwiches! The servers handed out free homemade pickles (which normally I hate, but these were delicious!) and buttons ("Fight for your right to HAVARTI") during our long wait. The line to get in was so long, it wrapped around the building and into South Park!

That being said, my "Piglet" (Tillamook aged white cheddar, artisan cured ham, apple mustard, rosemary butter) was very tasty! Crispy bread, savory ham, and melted cheeze YUM! It was $8, which is a little pricey to me, especially since the sandwich was pretty small, but did include a "cutie" orange.

This is going to be a great place: the servers are nice. Seating is "at the bar" inside on stools and outside on the patio. A great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Nicole C.

description:
I'm fairly certain that anyone who shared the excited anticipation of having a place DEDICATED to grilled cheese is of the mind that regular, run-of-the-mill grilled cheese is damn near perfect to begin with.  And thus, here in lies the conundrum:  There's nothing much to improve upon.  What the American has done is merely expand the definition of Grilled Cheese Sandwich, and therefore they are not really serving Grilled Cheese as we know and love it.  

They are serving Grilled Sandwiches With Many Contents, One of Which Is Always Some Type of Cheese.

I'm pretty sure that this is the definition of "Panini", but I'm not really up to speed on sandwich etymology.

Never the less:  Sammies are very tasty!  But alas, not $10 and a 20 minute wait tasty... maybe one or the other.

 (note:  I've been when there is no real line to speak of, but still waited 20 minutes for my food to be made).
author: Laura F.

description: Ridiculously amazing every time we visit! Their food never disappoints, this is one of the only places I've eaten at in SF that hasn't appeared to be over the top trendy, or over priced. It is what it is, and I like that. Excellent tomato soup.
author: Lindsay Y.

description: I absolutely love this place and would totally eat here every day (it's hard not to!). I walk by here on the way to work every day and have to resist going in daily. The food is just absolutely delicious and super reasonably priced.
author: Rowena L.

description:
Really good grilled cheese sandwiches. Nice options. Not pricey.

I could have used one of the lunch specials, but got there too early, so had to settle for the basic breakfast fare. Still a good deal.

The coffee was kind of marginal though, and no non-dairy options were available.
author: Joe G.

description:
I had high hopes for this place cause I love my grilled cheese, but I was also a little skeptical cause really how good could grilled cheese get that I would actually want to buy it instead of making it myself?

Well, I was wrong. It was definitely good enough to buy. Though I still believe it's a little on the expensive side at $7-10 per sandwich, it's quality enough that I'll forgive the expensive price tag. Had the farmer's breakfast -- sharp cheddar, roasted potatoes, bacon, egg, and chive butter....mmm...sooo delicious. The potatoes were a nice touch and who doesn't love some good bacon and eggs? The tomato soup was flavorful and smooth as well. A nice complement to a delicious grilled cheese. 

What really sold me on this place was their special that day however: dungeness crab mac and cheese with bacon. Bacon, crab, and mac n' cheese?!? not only did they combine three of my favorite things, they did it so well that I could probably have eaten three of those. The mac n' cheese had a nice kick to it and was the perfect cheesy consistency. The crab and bacon added a nice touch to it. 

Will try lunch next time. We came too early so lunch hadn't started yet. (Lunch starts at 12pm on weekends.)
author: Kim J.

description:
Theeeeee Bestt grilled cheese sandwich!! YUUUMMM-O!!

Great place to hang out during summer time + cookie and milk happy hour!! - where else can u get this?

Came here once - I ordered mouse trap with roasted tomato = cheese orgasm! the bread was toasted to perfection - crunchy on the outside and soft in the inside cause of the melted cheese.  soo goodd! i will definitely come back soon!

PS: There's a park right behind this place where you can chillaxing while eating ur cheese sandwich.
author: Ray S.

description:
Having now tried 3 of the sandwiches, I feel qualified to write a review (but fear not, my goal is to try them all)!

To date, I have tried the Windy City, the Wild Turkey, and the Jalapeno Popper. My favorite is the Popper, which has a fantastic spicy kick and bacon (BACON!). The Windy City was tasty with a healthy cheese flavor, while the Wild Turkey seemed a bit of a miss. I think the pickled onions overwhelmed the Havarti and the smoked turkey. Shame, cuz it had so much potential!

I've also had the smoky tomato soup, and it's fantastic (especially the croutons, mmm). Try the homemade sodas, the Vanilla Gingermint was a completely unique drink flavor.

This won't be the biggest meal you've ever eaten, and it's not cheap per se, but it's fun to eat a grown-up version of a childhood classic. It's definitely worth a try, but get there early (11:30-11:45)  to avoid the line.

Food: 4.5 stars
Value: 4 stars
Service: 5 stars
Ambience: 4 stars
author: Shannon B.

description:
It is interesting to read other Yelpers' reviews of this place and wonder if you should believe someone who thinks microwaving food can create better food of anything, or someone (ME) who likes food from divey diner food to fancy expensive cuisine. Take it from me, this place rocks. One thing you should know is that despite the name "Grilled Cheese Kitchen," it is not a place for plain simple white bread with melted cheese in the middle. For this, you might want to go to Denny's. I read that they serve grilled cheese sandwich with deep-fried Mozzarella sticks in the middle.

I ate their Breakfast Piglet sandwich with extra bacon. The combination of bacon, ham, farm fresh egg, apple mustard and rosemary butter required no additional seasoning and every ingredient was fresh and you can tell they choose their ingredients with care and passion. Bread was interesting and fresh (bought from a local bakery three blocks away), egg was fresh (hey...I eat pullet eggs bought from the SF Ferry Plaza Petaluma Farms folks that are three days old, so I know fresh eggs.), etc.etc. When I think of comfort food (grilled cheese and/or ham and cheese sandwiches would be categorized as such) and think of theirs, it's fancy comfort food in line with Bouchon's croque madame (they have a slight edge because it's got Béchamel sauce. Mmmmmm....), Royal Mama's (Croque Madame as well), Tartine Bakery's Croque Mousieur.

So, in summary, if you want simple plain grilled cheese, yes, you can make it yourself at home (hey, might as well, get the thingy that can burn an image of Jesus on them, why don't you?), or, think of having a fancy upgraded, sophisticated version of it with all the ingredients that are carefully chosen, eat here.
author: Yasuo S.

description:
Does this place need another review? Hell yeah - got to spread the cheese love!
This place is great for lunch and brunch: the Mushroom Gruyère was off the hook mushroom-melty-yuminess.  and the Sunday Brunch grilled cheese with goat cheese and McQuades fig & ginger chutney was freaking amazing -  it is a sweet option but you can add ham like I did for a yin/yang salty - sweet combo....
Keep up the good work guys and keep spreading the cheese love!!
author: Lisa B.

description: I've been here a few times with coworkers. It's a fun place for fancy grilled cheese sandwiches. I really like the jalapeno popper and the piglet. I like the flavor in the mousetrap, but it just has too much cheese that it's only good for a few bites. It's nice that they have a few options for add-ons too like bacon, arugala, caramelized onions, etc for a fair price. The one thing I wish is for them to grill the bread just a tad less. Sometimes it's so crunchy that it can be hard to eat.
author: Alice J.

description:
After a long wait, the AGCK is now open.  While the line was a bit long, my soup and sandwich was well worth the wait.  With fresh, local ingredients, everything came out to perfection.  I was rather impressed with the service that was being provided given the crowd that was there.  I've been to a number of places after they have recently opened, and everyone has their kinks to work out.  The only kink that I can see is they have a rather successful idea that has drawn a crowd.

Truly an homage to fromage.
author: Andy F.

description:
I give this place a solid 3.5 stars after one try and will upgrade if my next few visits are better.  I love that they've started with a niche and are bringing creativity and variation to what most people think of as a simple comfort food.  I also like that they're a moderately priced newcomer to a culinarily fallow neighborhood (hence the long lines).

However, the promise of a soothing, gooey, nationally-awarded grilled cheese sandwich fell a little flat for me... The combination of flavors (havarti, arugula, ancho chili jam...) was really nice, but the sandwich was entirely *too greasy* and the bread practically cut up my gums when I bit in.  I love my grilled cheese buttery & crisp on the outside, but still a little soft in the middle as the bread melds with the cheese.  Also, the "smoky tomato soup" was more bland than smoky.

That said, they're starting with a good concept that has the potential to be a local favorite if they can perfect the basics.
author: seema s.

description:
I wanted to like this place.  I really did.

I ordered the jalapeno popper, which was greasy, buttery and crispy - all normally good things.  But it was overbearing.  Everything was over the top, especially the apricot spread which had no heat to speak of.  It was actually a bit too sharp on my stomach.  I felt it the entire day so much so that dinner was not an option.

The place is a smarty thought concept place with cool, kitschy stiff on the wall, a very nice team behind the counter and an airy vibe that is unique to the area.  Whoever thought of it over a few beers is pretty proud of themselves right now - esp. as the line snakes into South Park. But that same person totally missed on the concept that food keeps people coming back.  And a lunch place needs to satisfy more than just people who love rich, oily, and small portions.  Lunch places need to cater to a group.  They need to have a greater breadth of choices.

4 stars for the overall concept.
2 stars on the execution.
1 star on how my stomach felt for ten hours.

guuurrpblipplegurp.  That was my stomach an hour after eating.
author: Tim T.

description:
This place is one of a kind! I have heard so much good things about it. Finally got a chance to have LUNCH here with my "twin sister". 

I like that they have out door sitting and parking lots are just right next to the place. There was a line for ordering throughout the dining period when we were there. People work there were fairly nice. We didn't wait too long for seats nor our food. Food was delicious and I was FULL after a sandwich and the tomato soup. It was a nice touch serving the lunch with a little tangerine.

I will definitely return to this place to try their breakfast. =)
author: Lianna D.

description:
Funny thing was I was craving a grilled cheese the night before and what do you know - we ended up right outside The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen. I was pleasantly surprised.

I was with a friend and we both ordered the special - half tomato soup and half grilled cheese. I tried the Moscone and it reminded me of Italy. I was in mozzarella and pesto heaven! The combo with the soup was really the way to go. My friend tried the Mousetrap with bacon and that was a classic and delicious choice. We were both satisfied and oiled up with yummy cheesy-ness in our bellies. 

I'd go again and I'd suggest if you're craving a greasy grilled cheese, hit it up!
author: Francesca F.

description: Great sandwiches, great soup. It's not a place with much room to sit down, more of a takeout place. But worth the wait, even if the line is long.
author: Michael P.

description:
I am a sucker for a good grilled cheese & this place didn't disappoint. 

Went around 2 on a Saturday & the line was only a few people long (totally reasonable). We tried the Piglet & Jalapeno Popper - they were both super delicious. The soup had great flavor but was a little thin for my taste... the pickle was yummy!

There's so much other good sounding/looking stuff on the menu, I'll definitely be back soon!
author: Susan K.

description:
Bougie grilled cheese sandwiches. Delicious? Yes. Having worked in South Park for 3 years, only recently leaving, it was a welcome change but... I really went in for the coffee, muffins, soups and salads all TOTALLY worth their price points and definitely a good change from other options in the area. 

When you work literally next door, it's definitely a convenience factor that's appealing, but for what it's worth, the care they put into their foods is pretty awesome all bougieness considered. Am I happy to have cheaper options where I currently work for equally delicious food? Yeah. Do I miss it? I might some day when all I really want is some sort of comfort food. 
Definitely worth trying once or twice.
author: Niki M.

description:
Ordered: The Red, White and Blue Plate Special $8
     (small sandwich + tomato soup or organic green salad)

First time here, so I opted for the basic grilled cheese - Mousetrap + roasted tomatoes and the Smoky Tomato Soup. The savory buttery goodness of the sandwich is enhanced by the tart yet creamy tomato soup.  I highly recommend this combo.  The bread is extremely crispy and the cheese just melted right.  I look forward to trying the other sandwiches on the menu.

Expect a line.
author: Ames L.

description:
My trip to the American Grilled Cheese EXPERIENCE was well anticipated. I found out I would be going to San Francisco and immediately went onto yelp to search for 'grilled cheese' in the area we were staying. To my amazement, this place showed up.

I dragged two friends on a 20 minute walk seemingly away from civilization - or our hotel at least - and emerged from an adorable tech hub green on south park to the most wonderful establishment.

I was a little disappointed to have so few options. We were there at 10.30am & they only had breakfast sandwiches and a limited few at that. Needless to say, we all got our melted cheese on, despite limitations.

I had the veggie without egg (allergies) & my friends had meaty alternatives. The sandwich was perfect and filling. The bread especially stood out to me as being a typically overlooked accomplishment.

It was cheap and the waitress was pretty nice. The cafe was very cute with grilled cheese artwork on the walls - I have to own that rooster zebra print..
author: Molly T.

description:
While the line was rather long, a waitress kept us entertained with a delicious drink sample - a housemade soda made with the most unique combination of ingredients. It is very difficult to decide upon a sandwich, but a friend and I decided to split the Mushroom Gruyere and the Moscone. The owner of this restaurant worked the register, and he was extremely friendly and we chatted it up lightly in spite of the fact that the restaurant was rather crowded. When we received our sandwiches, we sprinted to the nearby park because we could not wait to try the sandwiches! The aroma of the restaurant is to die for... 

As for the sandwiches themselves. The first bites of the Mushroom Gruyere, I cannot even describe in words. The bread was perfectly toasted and crispy, yet not too hard to bite into. The buttery goodness of the cheese and the mushrooms, balanced by the subtle flavor of leeks and potatoes (I couldn't really taste the potatoes, but it was damn good anyways!). After a few bites of the Mushroom Gruyere, I decided to try the Moscone. It was good as well, but not nearly as delicious as the mushroom. I suppose it depend what kind of mood you are in, and to me, this sandwich was similar to a mozarella sandwich you would order elsewhere, exept with melted cheese. I think the tomatoes and the pesto were too tart for me, and in my experiences, grilled cheese is just a real comfort food.

I would recommend splitting 2 sandwiches between you and a friend, simply because the flavors of these sandwiches are very strong and rich, and I think I would have gotten tired of the Mushroom Gruyere if I were to have eaten the entire thing. Still - extremely delicious sandwich, and I have not really stopped thinking about it since my visit. Definitely will return.
author: Shawna C.

description:
If you like to wait for one hour in line during lunchtime to pay $10+ for a grilled cheese sandwich, this is the place for you.  Otherwise, you're better off placing some fancy cheese between two slices of bread you've toasted/microwaved in the breakroom if you need a cheese sandwich fix.

They have one poor guy actually making the sandwiches in the back, frantically toasting the bread in the oven.  Sometimes it's burned, sometimes it's undercooked.  I don't blame the guy; he's way too busy.  The sandwiches are okay, but nothing great.  Definitely not $10 great.
author: Alison M.

description:
I enjoy a good grilled cheese sandwich every now and then and this place offers some suped up versions of an American classic. I came here a little after 1pm and it was pretty crowded but we didn't have to wait in a line nor did we have a problem finding a place to sit.

I ordered the Red, White and Blue Plate Special. I opted for their mushroom gruyere sandwich and the tomato soup. The sandwich was pretty good. The mushrooms were finely chopped so, at first glance, it looked like roast beef or something. I didn't know what to expect from having potatoes in the sandwich but they were so thinly sliced that I couldn't really taste it. The grilled bread offered a nice crunch and wasn't greasy at all. The melted cheeses...yummy, gooey goodness. I like the simple taste of tomato soup but didn't care too much for their smoky version. I think Tomatina, and even Trader Joe's, have a much better tasting tomato soup.

I'm sure I'll make my way back here again, there's a few other sandwiches I want to try. However, I'll probably pass on the tomato soup. This saddens me because grilled cheese and tomato soup is such a great combo *le sigh*
author: Christine P.

description:
I went here a couple days after it opened - and the 45 minute wait is not counting towards my rating, I promise.  The jalapeno popper was great (loved the apricot relish).  If it were either twice the size or half the price, I'd give this place 4 stars.  My co-workers had a pastrami sandwich (maybe it was a special?) and didn't like it.  $45 for 3 sandwiches is steep, especially since we had to stop by a convenience store on the way back since the guys were still hungry...

The owner was really cool though, bringing out samples of brownies to all the people waiting in line.
author: Katie P.

description:
It's grilled cheese, people.  It is hard to justify a $ 9 grilled cheese sandwhich when most people have no problem making them at home.  Portions were small.  Tomato soup had no taste.

I don't want to be too critical, since this place is brand new and kinks need to be worked out.  However, you can't run out of food on your third day of business.  At 1:30, basically half of the menu was not available ("sold out"), including the Piglet and the basic cheese.  Very poor planning.

The turkey sandwhich was tasty, but I wouldn't make the trip again.
author: Lewis F.

description:
I had the mouse trap with tomato and a passion fruit lemonade; So yummy. I wish it was more yummy, gooey cheese, but very tasty and perfectly cooked. 

Crazy line at lunch, but I don't hold that against them, it went pretty fast. Good service and very friendly, not pretentious.
author: Halley B.

description:
I've been there, and I will go back to try another sandwich.  To me, a grilled cheese and tomato soup are a comfort food best in winter, so I appreciate the variety of menu combinations and the ample patio for the warmer months.  A visit here evokes my inner child.

Since I don't live or work in SF, I have to make the time to come up for a sammie, so the line thing wouldn't bother me.   

i'm sure someone's already thought of it or mentioned in another review, but for those on a lunch hour is there a call in for orders or perhaps a kiosk up front to punch in order not too far in the future?
author: Claire S.

description:
Not bad food by any means. Overpriced for what you get though. $9 for the jalapeno popper which was good except there was not much cheese on it and it was a little overpowered by bread. I guess you're paying for the quality of ingredients but for what I paid, I don't plan on returning. 

The 7 other people I went with to this place ordered a variety of the sandwiches and weren't really wowed by what they got either.

Overall, not bad food but the high prices makes me feel like this place is kind of a gimmick.
author: Nick E.

description: pretty good quality for grilled sandwiches. I'd rather go here than The Melt. We ordered the Jalapeno Popper and theFoghorn one (forgot the full name) both were grilled perfectly and the ingredients all tasted very fresh. We also ordered a side of pickles for $1.50, I was expecting half, he was expecting 2 halves, but the order came with 4 halves!.....Will def come back again.
author: Linda L.

description:
Honestly, I was following this place since half a year before it opened. The buzz that it generated was incredible. The idea of the whole place was great, classic grilled cheese in an elegant way, yeah it seems like it would work.

The Good: People are very nice, the place looks great, love the feel to the whole restaurant

The Bad: Grilled cheese sandwiches need more cheese, possibly better bread. Tomato soup while suposedly capturing the classic feel, tasted barely better than cambells tomato soup (which I happen to love). The issue is where they try to make something artisan, Jalapeno Cheese Popper with bacon sandwhich. Great idea, horrible execution, needs more cheese, better bread. The soup, great idea with creme fraiche, and whatever else its suposed to taste like, nope just cambells. 

So in conclusion, its an idea that is there, but not executed well. Overpriced, food, but not overpriced on the staff.
author: Steven C.

description: Delicious - and what an awesome concept - wish we had one in Kansas City.  Maybe someday.  It was a little bit of a bummer that there is no overlap between breakfast and lunch - we arrived at 11:30, I wanting breakfast, my friends wanting lunch, but I understand that the kitchen is small and they can't do everything at once.  I ended up with the Farmer's breakfast sandwich which was amazing, my friends waited and ordered jalepeno grilled cheeses and tomato soup (the soup is SO good) - and we all shared the mac & cheese of the day, which had jalepeno and bacon in it and was ridiculously rich and tasty.  They could use some more indoor seating for windy days, but other than that, no complaints!
author: Jocelyn R.

description: I've seen The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen a few times while in the area and finally decided to give it a try.  Problem almost immediately...low energy dude behind the counter - wake up, it's time to work!!!  Two dudes were in front of me dissecting every item on the menu (I don't think they realized I was behind them) and low-energy dude just stood there staring into space waiting for them.  Finally, he asked them if he could take my order and they happily stepped aside.  I ordered the Club Turkey, then took a seat at the counter.  Within a few minutes, the sandwich appeared in front of me...looking quite small (at least there was a lone strawberry sharing the vast expanse of paper in the metal basket.)  To their credit, it was a good sandwich served quickly, using high quality ingredients.  Unfortunately, I was still hungry after I finished it - not a good feeling after dropping $9.  I would have been fully satisfied with another half sandwich.  In all, an OK place, but didn't dazzle me - especially low-energy guy at the counter who stared blankly as he dealt with customers and didn't bother to say "thank you" or even produce a half-smile.  Looks like I'll have to put TAGCK on my "probably won't return list." :(
author: Patrick L.

description:
The American Grilled Cheese Kitchen is not your regular home made grilled cheese sandwich you make after you come home from school. This place offers nouveau grilled cheese sandwiches with a creative use of ingredients. They have the regular old school grilled cheese sandwich and also the avant-garde grilled cheese sandwiches. 

I had the soup and sandwich combo AKA the Red, White & Blue Plate Specials and it came a bowl of piping hot tomatoes soup with crème fraiche and croutons and a full order (not half) of grilled Gruyere cheese with sautéed mushrooms, leeks, caramelized onions and thinly sliced potatoes on very crusty sour dough bread. The soup was so hearty and has a good kick of spices and smoky tomatoes flavor. It is definitely homemade and not the Campbell canned tomatoes soup you have at home. My combo meal truly hit the spot on a cold rainy Fall day like today. Although they say on their menu is a small sandwich for the soup and sandwich combo, I got a full (2 piece) sandwich and it was a lot of food for lunch at least. My sandwich was so flavorful and the perfect combination of ingredients.The binding flavors of leeks, onions and mushrooms are the perfect match. 

My friends had the Moscone, which has mozzarella, basil, roasted tomatoes and basil-lavender pesto and olive tapenade.
